title: Clemens von Pirquet’s term initially was dismissed in favor of Charles Richet’s word “anaphylaxis” (first coined in 1902 in two papers by Paul Portier and Richet, with Richet’s continued research leading to a Nobel Prize in 1913), but by the 1930s, anaphylaxis was increasingly being used to describe extreme reactions, while the concept of allergy brought together a broader host of problems, including asthma triggered by the presence of animals, the seasonal nature of hay fever and the discovery of pollen as a causative agent, and the isolation of histamine
